title: Cell cycle arrest of S. cerevisiae in conjunction with labeling of the cell wall
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Timing: 30 min for step 1
Timing: 3 h for step 2
Timing: 30 min for step 3
Cell Wall Staining to Distinguish Mother and Bud
Wash the cells twice in ice-cold PBS and then resuspend them in 0.5 mM sodium m-periodate in PBS (freshly prepared). Incubate for 15 min on ice. Wash 2× with ice-cold PBS.
Incubate on ice for 30 min with 0.5 mg/mL Texas Red--hydrazide or 13 mM CF488A Aminooxy in PBS (diluted from 100× stocks). Wash the cells twice and return them to growth medium ± methionine. Procedure 2, Lectin labeling.
Label the cells in growth medium by adding a 1/100 volume of rhodamine-Concanavalin A stock (1 mg/mL). Incubate for 15 min ice.
After two washes in growth medium ± methionine, resuspend the cells in medium ± methionine.
Cell Cycle Arrest
Grow shaking cultures of cells in synthetic medium lacking methionine. When they reach mid-log phase (OD600 = 0.5–1), sediment samples in Eppendorf tubes and resuspend in an equal volume of complete synthetic medium ([methionine] = 20 mg/liter). Shake for 3 h at 23°C.
Imaging
Sediment cell cultures.
Apply 0.5–1.0 μL samples of the pellet to the surface of agarose pads after exposure of the agarose by sliding off the upper slide.
Overlay with a No. 1 thickness coverslip.
For imaging in excess of 15 min duration, trim the agar to the dimensions of the coverslip and seal with vaseline to reduce drying.
Examine samples in a Deltavision RT epifluorescence microscope with an automated stage (Applied Precision, Inc) and an oil immersion objective (Olympus UPlanApo 100×/1.40; ∞/0.17/FN26.5).

Capture z-stacks at 0.2–0.5 μm intervals using a CCD digital camera (Photometrics CoolSnap HQ). % transmission = 100%, exposure time 0.05–1 s, field 1040 × 1040 pixels, binning 1 × 1. Collect through-focal series spanning a total of 6 μm. Remove out-of-focus light using the Softworks deconvolution program (http://www.sussex.ac.uk/gdsc/intranet/pdfs/softWoRx[href=http://www.sussex.ac.uk/gdsc/intranet/pdfs/softWoRx] user manual.pdf).
If it is not convenient to image living cells, fix the cultures by adding formaldehyde to a final concentration of 3.7% from a 37% stock in water, agitate for 5 min and then wash once with growth medium to quench free aldehydes. Store samples in water at this point for 1–2 days at 4°C before examination.
